document.title: Grade 6 – Exploratory Core – Language Arts/Science/Social Studies/Mathematics

6475169D8F314F4F993CE8DB5FB21F88.description: ●	Recognize the importance of cooperation in achieving individual and collective goals

FCB69E45B7FE47989906B689D5561FE4.description: ●	Compile and arrange alphabetically a list of sources including, author, title, type of publication, publisher and date of publication

25D571C0C5A149F3ADAAF39CF2852EDC.description: ●	 Recognize the role of Caribbean citizens in resolving regional issues.

C586C36C79BC42D7B35772905101561D.description: ●	Identify an existing regional problem, research multiple perspectives on the problem and its impact on the Caribbean and propose ways of solving the regional problems identified.

516AE10229B748D592E92103E40CF21C.description: ●	Explain why countries trade and assess the costs and benefits of intra-regional and international trade to CARICOM member states

BC525AD3A9404B60A2F1ECE6D9A7ECED.description: ●	Identify the goods and services traded among CARICOM member states and on the international market

22F6BFD2D2C9486B9B9F3B8909CCC053.description: ●	Identify regional organizations, describe their functions  and use evidence to assess how these organizations foster  integration ( CARICOM, CDEMA, CXC, UWI, West Indies Cricket team)

D4AC17F8DE3D425ABE6545926E4D1F9D.description: ●	Examine multiple sources and describe similarities and differences among Caribbean people and discuss the implications for integration of Caribbean countries

62B520483513492883F5EF73578E56B8.description: ●	Categorize Caribbean countries in a variety of ways

13B69DB6EEA14469991F1AA669AB4AA0.description: ●	Locate the member states of CARICOM on a map of the Caribbean

B5DAEDF412ED41EE937AC28B8E2070E6.description: ●	Using mathematical skills  to construct and interpret  a timeline showing  the stages of regional integration through which the Caribbean has passed

99790BE8A0D74C61805A5DD076D792BB.description: ●	 Define and use correctly the following terms; neighbour, cooperation, region, integration, multi-lateral, bi-lateral, common market

F2435922483A4CE6968FDD811837C94C.description: How can we benefit from cooperating with our Caribbean neighbours?

B7C073291002401097E530D6E182F2A3.description: •	Work cooperatively and individually to accomplish goals

D09B9E03AAC649D6BE78E5CF2FD994AA.description: •	Examine various cases of how justice is meted out to citizens of Jamaica, then develop criteria to judge the degree of fairness and use it to evaluate cases and propose just measures

E99D6CECE2CA48808687D57311ABE1B0.description: •	Compare the procedures for making decisions in a various settings (classroom, school, home, community, government)

2F7E48E46D3E45288E3532E1BADC283B.description: •	Evaluate various decisions made by the Jamaican government and discuss the intended and unintended impact of  these decisions on the Jamaican people then propose amendments to the decisions

655D79C0780242B6B2AEA7FB5B44CBB8.description: •	 Identify the goods and services  provided by government and explain how the government gets money to pay for these

CC10BCD905E244669E43FFED2313B393.description: •	Examine the activities of various leaders and then develop and justify a list of skills and qualities needed to lead at the national level

4DA54204FF144474B74FC92DF66BD52B.description: •	Identify persons in positions of power, describe how they acquired the position of power and  how their use of this power affects the freedoms and rights of others

4C098B7DAF4C480CB16EABD7A6375469.description: •	Examine an organizational chart of the structure of the Jamaican system of government  then describe it and make deductions about the relationship among members

D4265E7090FC4674A2B75006CA444C93.description: •	Examine the rights of a Jamaican citizen and develop a list of responsibilities of a citizen that complement these rights

D42CE00485ED44A3B9714C7DB20D6D9B.description: •	Distinguish between rights and responsibilities of citizens

9183BD4009F14E25A231D1A26474B1A0.description: •	Participate in activities that foster and develop responsible actions by citizens

7B5D2B5D972B4A56A56A9164DF090184.description: •	State the requirements for Jamaican citizenship

8AFF31EA76E94FC5B67D178F9980D2A0.description: •	Distinguish between local and central government

4F4602DCD614418ABC3C1011E54E7FAE.description: •	Develop working definitions and use correctly the following terms: citizen, leader, democracy, cabinet,  government, parliament, opposition, senate, monarch, constitution, vote, constituency

63B5F575E04F4A04845AC8F4BF9F925F.description: How are decisions made at the national level and how do these decisions affect us?

115090C1299F4E88AFA6FE446792BC30.description: ● Show respect for individuals who hold public office

802B958D9EBF424BACEF9A1612B53B7B.description: ● Show respect for our national symbols and emblems.

7C9B06F018FD4E90973362A164D44A2B.description: ● Examine images which show the changes in the Jamaican Coat-Of-Arms, justify the changes made

8BBCBAC282E049348D33B9C71BF21FEC.description: ●	Develop working definitions and use correctly the following concepts: emblem, flag, coat-of-arms, symbols, nationhood, anthem, crest, bearing, motto, patriotism

8A329C2E553C47AF933F7950890A5789.description: •	Analyse the purpose and enforcement of local laws and international agreements that are in place to protect the atmosphere and propose amendments to these or suggest new laws/agreements

763659741B1D4174A26A763428EB8CEE.description: •	 Use evidence to support arguments which show the importance of maintaining the Earth’s atmosphere.

CB0A7E8F708E46CD87151E7B9D630549.description: •	Assess multiple sources by distinguishing between facts  and myth/misconceptions  related to  atmospheric pollution

9BDA90FAFB204EDF94C46A1F41FEAED3.description: •	 Display willingness to acquire new information and use  it to understand the world in which we live

A06118B123B143A2B22D2594604F094D.description: •	Evaluate sources by distinguishing between facts and myths/misconceptions

444749F37B664863A810021435C04552.description: •	Distinguish one season from the next season

00A50851C40E4C40A1C37452A76523EA.description: •	Analyse information from diverse sources and make deductions about the effects of day and night and the seasons on man’s activities in the different hemispheres

DA6B31AF71C64D5DAEDA386A64503512.description: •	Explain how the revolution and tilt of the Earth’s axis causes the seasons and variation in the length of day and night.

1E85E48F6B7B4F9D95249FF892B908DE.description: •	Explain how rotation causes day and night

0F4C1897B17345198A9ECF2C2D288FC7.description: •	Ask questions about the movements of the Earth, gather information from multiple sources  and use evidence found to answer questions

F1EEA94D6A834543A1355AEA837661BA.description: •	Define and use correctly the following terms/ concepts: hemisphere, rotation, revolution, axis, orbit, year, day,  sunrise, sunset, equinox, solstice, season

650BF0B228EC4DC694C413C0131F2791.description: How do the movements which the Earth makes as it orbits the sun impact us?

C06A82D1E2C14F59B3CFEC085CE1D349.description: ●	Participate in activities and take individual action to reduce the negative impact of human activities on climate

8CDC51A4E67747E3BA5B3239E8B7D833.description: ●	Evaluate sources used by distinguishing between fact and opinion

C4B07AC333754258B356BC7436E94CA8.description: ●	Gather  evidence from multiple sources about the effects of climate change in the Caribbean the design strategies to  mitigate the impact of climate change on territories

051BED83FAF441CF89C5A6BC5936FB61.description: ●	Examine information from multiple sources on how human activities are determined by the climatic zone in which they live and justify their adaptations

68EC4D38A960468E92456034AB6DEAD5.description: ●	Formulate questions about why climate varies in different places and use evidence from various sources to explain how the interaction of factors determines the climate of places ( latitude, altitude, and distance from the sea)

BFC2F7DBF3964DF1A36194DE634F8A18.description: ●	Develop working definitions and use correctly the concepts: climatic zones, altitude, latitude, climate change

D26FB784A3FC4BA48F57886227F84C0B.description: •	Make decisions that show  responsibility and care for the environment

67A6DE04B3094112855A7904DDAE0518.description: •	Create thematic map showing  the name and location of major mountain ranges of the world (at least one in each continent)

49ACA472A4D14988A17AB3F16974E1CE.description: •	Design  models and develop strategies to reflect best practices for human activities in mountain/hill environments

7464879EB98A49E69D4096FE227CAAA6.description: •	Develop working definitions for and use correctly the following concepts/terms:  mountain, mountain range, hill, valley, plateaux, landforms, plains, forest reserve, summit, slopes

B93383AFC55A4724876DE1447C22CAA2.description: How are mountains important to people’s lives and how do human activities affect mountain environments?

C5980E8A8C3B4730AFBE7A002ED179F5.description: The Physical Environment and its Impact on Human Activities

D083E490510D4D20BFF00C0E569D609F.description: •	Weigh the arguments for and against being an independent nation  and draw conclusions about Jamaica’s decision to pursue independence

F3B9E6B983A74422B03F18878DD186FD.description: •	Show appreciation for the work done by individuals in Jamaica’s independence movement

72278EF043CD4219B271338629BE159C.description: •	Formulate questions about Jamaica’s decision to pursue independence and conduct research to answer these questions

1FD93B5792A64C5E8B1157477425FF8D.description: •	Explain the significance of independence day

A0A8208C047E44D0AB9833571A5E4F98.description: •	Compare how independence is commemorated in Jamaica and other countries

8982A9492DD84B22BA69481A98866684.description: •	Apply lessons learnt from the  lives of Marcus Garvey, Norman Manley and Alexander Bustamante to new situations

D9C5DDBE9408474DBB094F47D088D0F4.description: •	Examine, compare and evaluate multiple sources that outline  the life and work of Marcus Garvey, Norman Manley, Alexander Bustamante

34DC365F492C45D5A85B46DF657D2763.description: •	Develop working definitions for the following: independence, colonial rule, commonwealth, constitution, nation, monarchy, trade union, political party, self -government, universal adult suffrage, franchise, revolution

9DD1EF8E186B4A518DFBCACEC6CCABC0.description: •	Value the contribution of the East Indians and Chinese to Caribbean culture

D78B73C3D8DD4189887ABD02408C3AB4.description: •	Describe various strategies that are used to promote Caribbean culture

8D3D507DE8C841C3967AA8D0989C28C1.description: •	Describe and compare the traditions and celebrations of different ethnic groups by examining the following: Diwali(Divali)/ Hosay, Easter/Christmas, Crop Over, Chinese New Year

A404C30D925446B1AB726B76006C4EE0.description: •	Develop working definitions for and use the following:  indentured servant, indentureship, contract, festival, carnival, immigrant, migration, push and pull factors

4489E8FF77854D6F993A17153F842693.description: How can we promote and preserve our Caribbean culture?
